ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a better understanding of Aztec and greater Mesoamerican history, ethnography, and archaeology.

Highly recommend this course if you are even remotely interested in aztec history. Even though the class has archaeology in its title, there is not really any sort of archeological study conducted in the class, it is pretty much just an aztec history course that gives extremely interesting insight into aztec culture and as a whole, Mesoamerican culture at the time.

I learned about the history, culture, and society of the Aztecs from an archeological and ethnohistorical view. Although I do not plan to go into either field, I feel confident reading papers for both.
I learned so much on Mesoamerica and the Aztecs,
learned about Aztec culture, history, and society, as well as some introductory concepts in anthropology + ethnohistory

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course has no weaknesses, it is the perfect social sciences course. Workload is low and lectures are very interesting and engaging. Professor Oswaldo very qualified and constantly attempts to engage us in the class through discussions and trips to the art gallery and even botanical gardens.

Strengths: content is amazing and the professor is a lot of fun!

Weaknesses: Wish there was more clarity on some of the assignments

The prime strength of the course was the multiple engaging field trips we took to various locations on campus. Marsh botanical garden, the art gallery, Peabody museum, etc. Weaknesses were that sometimes the course lacked engagement, as the lecture style did not seems as effective as when we discussed topics as a class.

strengths: fascinating subject material, lots of experiential learning in visits to galleries, libraries, etc., discussion incorporated into class rather than discussion sections

weaknesses: organization was a bit unclear and heavy reading load. more prioritization in readings would have helped me do a few rather than just avoiding them all because there were too many

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! It was an amazing course!

Yes, this class is very interesting and relative to other Yale courses, pretty easy. Workload is low and the class content is very interesting. Highly recommend with Professor Oswaldo, he is an expert in his field.
Yes! If you want a fun class where you will actually learn stuff, do take it!

If they are interested or attached to the topic, yes. To be fair, Aztec Archaeology and Ethnohistory is such a niche topic. The majority of the class had roots in Mexico, so class discussions were kept exciting and memorable.
I would definitely recommend this course. It was an extremely interesting subject and well worth the time put into it.
I would recommend this course to someone looking to learn about the ancient Americas
